body: The error will go away if you set the error handler to return `?bool`, but this error should also probably not happen in the first place.

I found these snippets:
<details>
<summary>https://psalm.dev/r/0c1002dd00</summary>

```php
<?php

/** @param callable():?bool $c */
function takesCallable(callable $c) : void {}

takesCallable(function() { return; });
```

```
Psalm output (using commit 45ea5d0):

ERROR: InvalidArgument - 6:15 - Argument 1 of takesCallable expects callable():(bool|null), Closure():void provided
```
</details>

Not convinced this is fixed. I extracted the code and pasted it to https://psalm.dev/r/8ac153541e.

It still complains.

The way I read the error message - and that of course might be wrong ;) - implies to me that psalm doesn't like the `[$obj, 'method']` construct as it seemingly detects it as simple `array` (which is technically is of course) but not something PHP considers callable.

Hm, could it be that the return type is missing parens? If I use the type copied verbatim from the error message in a param docblock, it's interpreted as `callable|null`: https://psalm.dev/r/21270719ec

I found these snippets:
<details>
<summary>https://psalm.dev/r/21270719ec</summary>

```php
<?php
/** @param callable(int, string, string=, int=, array<array-key, mixed>=):bool|null $_p */
function f($_p): callable {
  return $_p;
}
```

```
Psalm output (using commit 211f014):

ERROR: NullableReturnStatement - 4:10 - The declared return type 'callable' for f is not nullable, but the function returns 'callable(int, string, string=, int=, array<array-key, mixed>=):bool|null'

ERROR: InvalidNullableReturnType - 3:18 - The declared return type 'callable' for f is not nullable, but 'callable(int, string, string=, int=, array<array-key, mixed>=):bool|null' contains null
```
</details>

> it's interpreted as `callable|null`

And it's actually proper signature, as you may call `set_error_handler(null);` to remove the error handler.
Oh sorry @theseer, my mistake – this should work: https://psalm.dev/r/e78ad276ca

It certainly does - but is that also correct? I mean, technically the specified return value of the method is not what is happening ;)

But then, maybe that's an edge case of an edge case ;)

> I mean, technically the specified return value of the method is not what is happening ;)

Yeah, I'm surprised it's not reported. I think it should require `@return never-return`: https://psalm.dev/r/ef21c8743b

> Yeah, I'm surprised it's not reported.

`never-return` is a bottom type – the subtype of all possible types, so it's fine to throw when the function says it should return a value.

> never-return is a bottom type

Ah, makes sense. Thanks for clarification.

issue.title: Refactors files app commands

repository.name: server
repository.description: ☁️ Nextcloud server, a safe home for all your data

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
I have made some adjustments to the `apps/files/lib/Command` classes to improve the code readability.

The improvements in this PR include but are not limited to:

- Using PHP8's constructor property promotion
- Adding return types
- Replacing return code integers with more readable strings.
- Using early returns

issue.title: refactor: Update package to support php >=8 and Psr Log 2 || 3
issue.body:
Updating dependencies to be able to work with newer Psr/Log BREAKING CHANGE: we are dropping support for PHP 7.x and Psr/Log 1.x

<!--
Thanks for contributing—you rock!

Please note:
- These comments won't show up when you submit the pull request.
- Please make sure your changes respect the WordPress Coding Standards:
  - https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/coding-standards/
- In case you introduced a new action or filter hook, please also include inline documentation:
  - https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/inline-documentation-standards/php/
- Please create tests, if you can.
-->

This pull request fixes issue #.

#### What's Included in This Pull Request

* Drop support for PHP 7.x
* Drop support for Psr/Log 1.x and support Psr/Log 2.x || 3.x
* Update of PHP Unit to v9 since it was required to achieve the goal
* Update of Psalm since it was required to achieve the goal
* Require the test class from the new package since the test folder was deleted from the source
* Added new strategy in the matrix of PHPUnit testing to use --prefer-lowest and resolve to psr/log v2 during the installation
* Added other PHP static analysis using with different PHP versions
* Fixed Psalm issues mostly adding new annotations since Psalm does not know about different WP versions
* Updated PHPUnit config to remove dprecation warning
* Changed the usage of assertRegexp in test to the new method as it will be deprecated in PHPUnit 10
